(4) Rules and regulations pertaining to food service (adopted by the department of human resources (ch. 290-5-14) and the county board of health and being the county board of health rule V as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the county board of health pertaining to food service; (5) Rules and regulations pertaining to public swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks (adopted by the department of human resources (ch. 290-5-57) and the county board of health and being the county board of health rule VI as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the county board of health pertaining to public swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks; (6) Rules and regulations pertaining to tourist accommodations (adopted by the department of human resources (ch. 290-5-18) and the county board of health and being the county board of health rule VI as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the county board of health pertaining to tourist accommodations; (7) Rules and regulations pertaining to body art (adopted by the county board of health and being the county board of health rule VIII as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the county board of health pertaining to body art. (Ord. of 10-9-1989, § I) Sec. 18-2. - Implementation and enforcement. The duty of implementation and enforcement of these regulations rests with the county board of commissioners, and by virtue of this chapter is hereby expressly delegated to the county board of health who is hereby charged with promulgation of sufficient procedures for ensuring compliance with these rules and regulations by the citizens of the county. The county board of health is directed to implement procedures which will ensure that the citizens of the county will receive all procedural rights to which they are entitled under the laws of the state. (Ord. of 10-9-1989, § II) Sec. 18-3. - Penalty. Any violation of the rules and regulations hereby referenced shall be a violation of this chapter and shall be a misdemeanor offense. Any violator shall be subject to the general penalties described in section 1-14. Any failure of payment of inspection fees listed within the fee schedule adopted by the county board of health and approved by the county board of commissioners within 60 days of first notice, may result in suspension of permit. (Ord. of 10-9-1989, § III) Sec. 18-4. - Magistrate's court jurisdiction. The magistrate's court of the county shall have jurisdiction over violators of this chapter and all procedures for enforcement of such chapter shall be as provided in article 4, ch. 10 of title 15, Official Code of Georgia. Complaints of violation of any provision of this chapter shall be brought before the magistrate's court by a designated representative of the county board of health and shall be prosecuted through that court. (Ord. of 10-9-1989, § IV)

div.head: Chapter 20 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND MOBILE HOMES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 20-1. - Placement of used and pre-owned mobile or manufactured homes. (a) It resolved by the county commissioners of the county, and it is hereby resolved by authority of the same that the regulations governing the placement or movement of used and pre-owned mobile or manufactured homes within or into the county are hereby adopted as follows: (1) No used or pre-owned mobile or manufactured home being moved into the county shall be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in this county without an inspection. However, any mobile or manufactured home that is located in the county as of April 15, 2004, shall not be affected by passage of the resolution from which this section was derived and such existing mobile home shall be freely transferable and relocated in the county, unless such existing mobile or manufactured home was manufactured prior to U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department construction standards. (2) Permit requirements. No permit shall be issued under this chapter, unless a septic tank permit has been obtained from the health department. All mobile homes being moved into the county shall conform to all permitting requirements. No mobile or manufactured home permit shall be issued unless proof of payment of current year's taxes is provided. (b) Violations. Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be brought before the magistrate court for violation of this chapter and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount up to $1,000.00. Such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which any violation of any provision of this chapter is committed, continued or permitted by that person and shall be punished by a fine in an amount up to $1,000.00 per day for the violation. (Res. of 12-13-2010) Secs. 20-2—20-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR PRE-OWNED MANUFACTURED HOMES
Sec. 20-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Assignee means any bank, financing institution or any person purchasing a retail installment contract, that has as security, a manufactured home. Pre-owned manufactured home means any manufactured home as defined in Georgia Law 8-2-131(3) that has been previously utilized as a residential dwelling. Retailer shall be synonymous with a dealer, as defined in Georgia Law 8-2-131(3), that has been previously utilized as a residential dwelling. (Res. of 12-13-2010, § A) Sec. 20-22. - Facilities required. (a) Sanitary facilities. Every pre-owned manufactured home shall contain not less than a kitchen sink, lavatory, tub or shower, and a water closet all in working condition when properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. Every plumbing fixture and water and waste pipe shall be in a sanitary working condition free from leaks and obstructions. (b) Hot and cold water supply. Every kitchen sink, lavatory and tub or shower in a pre-owned manufactured home must be connected to a supply of both cold and hot water. (c) Water heating facilities. Every pre-owned manufactured home shall have water-heating facilities in a safe, working condition. (d) Heating facilities. (1) Every pre-owned manufactured home shall have heating facilities in safe, working condition. Where a central heating system is not provided, each manufactured home shall be provided with facilities whereby heating appliances may be connected. (2) Unvented fuel-burning heaters shall be prohibited, except for gas heaters listed for unvented use and the total input rating of the unvented heaters is less than 30 BTU per hour per cubic feet of room content. (3) Unvented fuel-burning heaters shall be prohibited in bedrooms. (4) In lieu of inspecting the heating facilities of a pre-owned manufactured home, the retailer may request a heating inspection by a qualified third party. Approval by such person will be accepted as compliance with those portions of the safety standards established herein which pertain to heating systems. (e) Smoke detector. Every pre-owned manufactured home shall be provided with a state approved smoke detector, installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations and listing. (f) Windows. Every habitable room, excluding bathrooms, kitchens, and hallways, shall have at least one window that can be opened, facing directly to the outdoors. Glass must be in the windows. (g) Ventilation. Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight which can be opened, or such other device that will ventilate the room. (h) Electrical. (1) Distribution panels. Distribution panels shall be in compliance with the approved listing, complete with required breakers or fuses, with all unused openings covered with black covers approved and listed for that purpose. (2) Electrical system. The electrical system (switches, receptacles, fixtures, etc.) shall be properly installed, wired and shall be in working condition. The pre-owned manufactured home shall be subjected to an electrical continuity tests to ensure that all metallic parts are properly bonded. (3) Third party inspection. The retailer may, in lieu of inspecting the electrical and heating systems of a pre-owned manufactured home, request an electrical inspection by a qualified third party. Approval by such a person will be accepted as compliance with those portions of the safety standards established herein which pertain to electrical systems. (i) Exterior walls. The exterior of the home shall be free of loose or rotting boards or timbers and any other conditions that might admit rain or moisture to the interior portions of the walls or to the occupied spaces of the pre-owned manufactured home. (j) Exterior siding. The exterior siding of the pre-owned manufactured home shall be free of rot and rust and must be uniform in appearance. (k) Roofs. Roofs shall be structurally sound and have no obvious defects, which might admit rain or cause moisture to collect on the interior portion of the home. (l) Interior floors, walls, and ceiling. Every floor, interior wall and ceiling shall be kept in sound condition to prevent the admittance of rain or moisture. (Res. of 12-13-2010, § B) Sec. 20-23. - Exception for homes purchased for repair. (a) If a pre-owned home is to be sold as is for purposes of repair prior to occupancy, the sales agreement and/or contract shall specifically state that the purchaser understands that the home is not habitable in its present condition and that purchaser must bring home into compliance with the specified standards. (b) No home may be placed for occupancy until the standards herein are met. (Res. of 12-13-2010, § C)

div.head: Chapter 22 - NUISANCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq.
Sec. 22-1. - Junk vehicles; junk scraps; household appliances. (a) It shall be illegal for any owner or occupant to store in public view for a period of more than 30 days a junk motor vehicle, junk scrap parts; abandoned, dilapidated mobile homes; or household appliances on property within the county that can be viewed from a state, county, or other public road. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Junk motor vehicle means: (1) Any motor vehicle which is not capable of locomotion under its own power due to missing components such as motors, wheels, tires or any other parts necessary to make the vehicle operable; wrecked, scrapped, ruined or dismantled motor vehicles. (2) Any motor vehicle that does not comply with Georgia Traffic Law, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq., equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, in its entirety. Junk scraps mean old or scrap copper, wood furniture, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash, rubber, debris, or waste; junked or dismantled automobile parts; or iron, steel, inoperable household appliances and other old scrap ferrous or nonferrous material. (c) The occupant of any lot that stores a junk motor vehicle, junk scrap parts or household appliances, shall be given 30 days' notice to remove the property or build a privacy fence at least six feet high prior to issuance of a written summons. If the occupant has not complied with the request, the matter will be turned over to the magistrate court of the county. (d) Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-14, per occurrence, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20. (Res. of 4-21-2004)

div.head: Chapter 24 - OFFENSES[1]
Chapter 26 - PLANNING
div.p: Sec. 26-1. - Lakeland-Lanier County Planning Commission membership. The Lakeland-Lanier County Planning Commission shall consist of eight members. Four of the members shall be residents of the City of Lakeland appointed by the mayor and city council of the city and three of the members shall be residents of the county appointed by the commissioners of roads and revenues of the county. The terms of the members shall be for four years, except that in the appointment of the first Lakeland-Lanier County Planning Commission under the terms of this chapter, one of the county-appointed members shall be appointed for a term of two years and two for terms of four years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the commissioners of roads and revenues who shall also have the authority to remove any county-appointed member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Res.*, § 1) *Editor's note—Number and adoption date for this resolution were not available at the time of publication of this Code. Sec. 26-2. - Organization; rules; staff and finances. The Lakeland-Lanier County Planning Commission shall elect its chairperson from among its members. The term of chairperson shall be one year with eligibility for re-election. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the municipality or the county. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken, shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the governing authority of the city and the county. (Res.*, § 2) *Editor's note—Number and adoption date for this resolution were not available at the time of publication of this Code. Sec. 26-3. - Powers and duties. From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then said planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (Act No. 358 as amended). (Res.*, § 3) *Editor's note—Number and adoption date for this resolution were not available at the time of publication of this Code.

div.head: Chapter 28 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1]
Chapter 30 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries pursuant to contract, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Garbage means rubbish, trash, household waste, paper and cardboard containers, cans, bottles and the like which usually and customarily originate within a place of business or residence. Garbage container means a can or container of any size placed in the county for the collection of garbage. (Ord. of 5-8-1995, preamble) Sec. 30-2. - Littering prohibited; generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, cast, or deposit upon any highway, alley, or any yard or premises, public or private, any filth of any kind, or cans, paper, trash, paper containers, rubbish, bottles, or any other form of litter or waste whatsoever. (Ord. of 5-8-1995, § 1) Sec. 30-3. - Items other than garbage. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to place, put or throw on, in or upon any garbage container, any object of whatever size or description except garbage which consist of rubbish, trash, household waste, paper and cardboard containers, cans, bottles and the like which usually and customarily originate within a place of business or residence. (Ord. of 5-8-1995, § 2) Sec. 30-4. - Rummaging through garbage prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than designated employees in performing their normal duties, to rummage through, separate or remove any object placed in or upon such garbage container. (Ord. of 5-8-1995, § 3) Sec. 30-5. - Defacing garbage prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to paint upon, deface or in any way cause any damage whatsoever to any garbage container placed upon the premises for the collection of garbage. (Ord. of 5-8-1995, § 4) Sec. 30-6. - Penalty. Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-14 and also shall be subject to criminal prosecution by the proper authorities as provided by law and the ordinance of the county. (Ord. of 5-8-1995, § 5) Sec. 30-7. - Adopt the county solid waste management plan. The county chairperson and the county commissioners do hereby adopt the 2015 Lanier County Solid Waste Management Plan amendment to the South Georgia Multi-Jurisdictional Solid Waste Management Plan and transmit notification to the South Georgia Regional Development Center and the state department of community affairs for certification of completion. (Res. of 6-13-2005) Secs. 30-8—30-32. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICES
Sec. 30-33. - Title. This article shall be known as the "Ordinance Regulating the Provision of and Assessment of Fees for Residential Solid Waste Services within the Unincorporated Areas of Lanier County." (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 1) Sec. 30-34. - Authority. This article is authorized under article IX, § II, ¶ III(2) of the state constitution. (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 2) Sec. 30-35. - Scope of article. The scope of this article shall include all dwelling units within the unincorporated areas of the county. (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 3) Sec. 30-36. - Compliance. The owner and/or resident of each dwelling unit within the unincorporated areas of the county shall dispose of all residential solid waste in compliance with all state and federal laws, and in compliance with the terms of this chapter. (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 4) Sec. 30-37. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dwelling unit means one or more rooms with kitchen facilities designed as a unit for occupancy by one family for cooking, living and sleeping purposes. (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 5) Sec. 30-38. - Services and payment of fees. (a) All fees imposed under this article shall be due and payable monthly within 30 days of invoice. (b) The resident and/or owner of each dwelling unit shall pay a fee for residential solid waste services in an amount as set by the commissioners of the county and shall use the residential solid waste services provided or, if such dwelling unit is occupied by someone other than the owner, the owner shall require as a condition of occupancy that the occupant utilize such residential solid waste services. (c) A notice of payment due shall be mailed to the resident and/or owner of each dwelling unit monthly, on the first business day of the month in which services are to be rendered. (d) Any account which has not been paid in full after 45 days from the date of invoice may be turned over to an agency or attorney for purposes of collection through any lawful means, upon the sole discretion of the commissioners of the county. (e) The fee for residential solid waste services will be due and owing by the resident and/or owner of each dwelling unit each month, regardless of whether a notice is sent to or received by the resident and/or owner. (f) A statement of the account and past balances of an owner and/or resident of a dwelling unit may be mailed to the owner from time to time when outstanding balances for monthly fees remain unpaid. (g) An owner of a dwelling unit may designate the occupant thereof to make payment of the fees. However, the owner of the dwelling unit will remain legally responsible for payment of the fees. (h) Upon notice to the county board of commissioners that a resident and/or owner has not paid the invoice for services, a letter will be mailed requesting that said sums be paid within ten days. If said fee is not paid, said account will be turned over to the magistrate court of the county. (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 6) Sec. 30-39. - Violation and misdemeanor. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-14. (Ord. of 2-8-1999, § 7)

div.head: Chapter 32 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Taxation power of county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); county taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-220.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 32-1. - The county judicial in rem tax foreclosures. (a) The governing authority of the county does hereby declare that it will follow the requirements of S.B. 383 as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq., relating to tax sales, regarding judicial in rem tax foreclosures. (b) The duly elected tax commissioner for the county shall have the authority to commence tax foreclosure and to file petition with the county superior court in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq., relating to tax sales. (c) As so provided by the state law the county may undertake judicial in rem tax foreclosures for delinquent taxes. (Res. of 5-14-2007) State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq. Sec. 32-2. - Authorization of tax commissioner to waive penalties and interest on unpaid ad valorem taxes under certain conditions. (a) The board of commissioners does hereby authorize the county tax commissioner, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-242 and any other applicable law, to waive penalties and/or interest on unpaid ad valorem taxes under the following conditions: (1) Notice to the taxpayer was not sufficient, such as in the case of a new purchaser that was not reflected in the tax commissioner's files or an address error in the tax file; (2) Dire illness of the taxpayer that resulted in the taxpayer being hospitalized, in a nursing or rehabilitative home, or otherwise not present in the home for an extended period of time; (3) Where the penalty and interest is less than $5.00; (4) Taxpayer has provided substantial evidence of assessment error. (b) The waiver for the reasons listed in subsection (a) of this section may be issued when the tax commissioner reasonably determines that the default giving rise to the penalty and/or interest to be waived was due to reasonable cause and not due to gross negligence or willful neglect or disregard of the law or of regulations or instructions issued pursuant to the law and when the interest to be waived accrues. (Res. of 6-13-2011(2); Res. of 2-11-2013) Secs. 32-3—32-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Georgia Emergency Telephone Number 911 Service Act of 1977, O.C.G.A. § 46-5-120 et seq.
Sec. 32-23. - Imposing charge on wireless telephone subscribers for E-911. A wireless enhanced 911 charge shall be imposed upon each wireless telecommunications connection subscribed to by subscribers whose billing address is within the jurisdiction of the county at the rate of $1.50 per month per wireless connection provided to each telephone subscriber. (Res. of 3-9-2009) Sec. 32-24. - 911 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2, there is hereby imposed a prepaid wireless 911 charge as defined by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(a)(4) upon every prepaid wireless retail transaction occurring within the jurisdiction of the public service answering point in the amount of $0.75. (Ord. of 9-12-2011, § 1) Sec. 32-25. - Collection of 911 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. Prepaid wireless 911 charges collected by sellers shall be remitted to the commissioner of the department of revenue at the times and in the manner provided by ch. 8 of title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated with respect to the sales and use tax imposed on prepaid wireless calling service. (Ord. of 9-12-2011, § 2) Sec. 32-26. - Depositing of funds; use of funds. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(5), funds received by this county from charges imposed by this chapter shall be deposited in the Emergency Telephone System Fund maintained by this county pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134 and kept separate from general revenue of the jurisdiction; all such funds shall be used exclusively for the purposes authorized by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(f). (Ord. of 9-12-2011, § 4) Secs. 32-27—32-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ENERGY EXCISE TAX
Sec. 32-56. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dealer, energy, local sales and use tax and purchaser shall have the same meanings as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 1) Sec. 32-57. - Imposition; rate; remitting; recovery; liabilities. In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110 et seq., there is imposed within the territorial limits of the special district created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-111, an excise tax on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy when such sale, use, storage, or consumption would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq., but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 2) Sec. 32-58. - Excise tax rate; phase-in. (a) Such excise tax shall be levied and collected by the governing authority of the county pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112 and 48-13-114 and as provided in this section. (b) Except as otherwise provided in this section, the rate of such excise tax shall be phased in over a four-year period as follows: (1) For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 25 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy, but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (2) For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 50 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy, but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (3) For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 75 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy, but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and (4) On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 100 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy, but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (c) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2(c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in subsection (b)(1) through (3) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in subsection (b)(4) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016, limitation in that subsection (b)(4). (d) After initial phase-in. (1) Following such initial imposition of the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the county shall be directed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the special district, but in no event more than two percent. (2) In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district decreases from two percent to one percent, the rate of the excise tax under this chapter shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. (3) In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district increases from one percent to two percent, the rate of the excise tax under this chapter shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 3) Sec. 32-59. - Imposition; remittance; recovery. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c), such excise tax shall be: (1) Imposed only at the time sales and use tax on the sale or use of such energy would have been due and payable under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30, but for the exemption under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (2) Due and payable in the same manner as would be required under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq., except as otherwise provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq.; (3) A debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts; (4) Remitted to the governing authority of the county by the dealer collecting such excise tax; and (5) A liability of the dealer at the applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of excise taxes collected from purchasers, whichever is greater. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 4) Sec. 32-60. - Exemption certificates. (a) The governing authority of the county, or the collecting officer appointed under section 32-63, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the special district and to ascertain whether such a purchaser has completed a uniform exemption certificate provided from the website of the state department of revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser for the exemption under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this chapter. (b) An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates. No penalty shall attach to such provider for failure to collect the excise tax under this chapter when it has properly collected and remitted local sales and use taxes on such energy where the purchaser would have qualified for the uniform exemption certificate, but failed to apply for such certificate or where the purchaser received such certificate, but failed to file it with the energy provider. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 5) Sec. 32-61. - Commencement of collections. The excise tax imposed pursuant to this chapter shall become effective on January 1, 2013, and shall be due and payable to the governing authority of the county monthly on or before the 20th day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this chapter during the preceding calendar month. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 6) Sec. 32-62. - Allocation, distribution, and expenditure of proceeds. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114(b), the excise tax proceeds shall be allocated and distributed by the governing authority of the county at the end of each calendar month. An amount equal to one percent of such proceeds collected by the county shall be paid into the general fund of the county to defray the costs of collection and administration. (b) The remainder shall be distributed in accordance with the intergovernmental agreement as required under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114(b) and (c). Within 30 days following the end of each calendar month, the remainder shall be distributed to the general fund of the county and the general fund of each participating municipality in accordance with the applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114(c)(1) or (2) as follows: (1) If two local sales and use taxes are in effect in the special district, an amount equal to one-half of the proceeds shall be distributed to the general fund of the county and the general fund of each participating municipality located in the county according to the same proportionate share as specified under the distribution provisions of the first local sales and use tax and an amount equal to one-half of the proceeds of the excise tax shall be distributed to the general fund of the county and the general fund of each participating municipality located in such county according to the same proportionate share as specified under the distribution provisions of the second local sales and use tax; or (2) If only one such local sales and use tax is in effect in the special district, then the proceeds of the excise tax shall be distributed to the general fund of the county and the general fund of each participating municipality located in the county according to the same proportionate share as specified under the distribution provisions of the local sales and use tax. (c) Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, proceeds of the excise tax deposited in the general fund of the county may be expended for any lawful purpose as determined by the governing authority of the county. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 7) Sec. 32-63. - Administrative provisions; audits; examinations; collecting officer. (a) The governing authority of the county shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer for collection and administration of the excise tax under this chapter. (b) The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this chapter, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. The collecting officer, or the designee of the collecting officer, is specifically authorized to examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, or other facilities of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax under this chapter. (c) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-118, as part of the audit report required under O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7, the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this chapter. (Ord. of 12-10-2012, § 8)
